description: From Middle English mawmet, from Anglo-Norman maumet, shortened form of mauhoumet, mahumet; deriving from Andalusian Arabic مَحُمَّدْ‎ (“Maḥummad”), ultimately derived from Arabic Muhammad.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A false god; an idol. [13th–17th c.]
examples: Moloc that mawmett. there darre no man wt ſayThe Reſte of ſuche Reconyng may make a fowle fraye

entries.meaning: A doll or puppet; a lifeless figure, an effigy, a scarecrow. [from 15th c.]
examples: He didn't want to go, and I didn't want him to go; and we stood there like two mommets and there was nothing we could say.

entries.meaning: A contemptible person; a weakling, a fool. [from 16th c.]
examples: Blind, deaf, insensate driveler!—Torpid, blockish, brainless mammet!
